TEXT.English: The Road to War includes a number of new concepts to Civilization IV. Please take the time to read about them here to get the most out of The Road to War.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]1. Play modes - The Road to War contains three modes of play: Accurate Historical Events, Random Historical Events and Open Play. To play with war and peace events occuring on their historical dates, choose Accurate Historical Events when prompted. Random Historical Events also has war and peace events occuring, but they occur near to their historical date. Open Play enables all options within the game and has no war and peace events. This is the best mode for "What-if" games.[NEWLINE]NOTE: If you choose one of the two event options you will not be able to influence your nation's ideology or forge diplomatic treaties.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]2. Add-on Packs - There will be add-on packs available for downloading for The Road to War after release. These add-on packs will include patches, add new features, new options or new scenarios. Please visit http://rtw.apolyton.net to obtain these add-ons.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]3. Ranged Bombardment - Bombarding units can now bombard in the field, as well as bombard cities. These units can bombard city defences, units and tile improvements. You may also perform coastal bombardments. For help hold the cursor over the bombard mission icon.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]4. Paratroopers - Paratroopers function slightly differently to their Beyond the Sword counterpart. In The Road to War paratroopers will be able to gain the promotion Paratrooper which enables them to land and move or fight in the same turn. For help hold the cursor over the paradrop mission icon.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]5. Anti-Air units - Anti-Air units are land-based units which can intercept incoming enemy aircraft. This will occur automatically. Anti-Air units may gain the Searchlights promotion to increase their interception abilities.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]6. Unit Production - For most units in The Road to War there is a production chain required before the city is able to build them. For example: to build a tank, the city requires a Vehicle Factory, which in turn requires access to resources. Barracks will give their domain's units extra experience when built.[NEWLINE]NOTE: A city requires an Airforce Base before airlift and paradrop missions become available.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]7. Airlifting / Interceptions - Some changes have been made to air units to allow for greater air interaction. You may now airlift 3 units from a city with an Airforce Base, and supply unlimited troops to a city with an Airforce Base via airlifting. Also, fighters are able to intercept multiple times per turn.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]8. Airbombing - The airbomb mission has been split into three seperate missions. You may now airbomb infrastructure (city defences and tile improvements), airbomb a city's civil buildings (non-defence buildings), and airbomb factories. When bombing civil buildings and factories there is a chance that a building will be destroyed.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]9. Industry Civics - The Road to War simulates the increasing buildup of the Allies production facilities by utilising Industry Civics. Fascist nations will begin on a war production level but other nations must research industrial technologies to open Industrial Civics to them. These civics bring massive benefits in regards to unit production speed and unit support costs.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]10. Bitter Winter - Winter is long and harsh in Eastern Europe. Be wary of winter months if operating in these areas, as your units movement and healing rates will be hampered. USSR and Finland begin with Winter Warfare promotion which counters these conditions to some extent, and other nations may promote units to this level after Combat II.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]I hope you enjoy The Road to War. If you have any comments and to access new add-on packs please visit http://rtw.apolyton.net[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Dale Kent - Designer and Developer[NEWLINE]David Sobotka - Movies and Interface[NEWLINE]Tony Kiehl - Unit/Leader/Terrain Artwork[NEWLINE]Thank you to the unit makers of CivFanatics.

TEXT.English: Vichy France was established after France surrendered to Germany, and took its name from the government's administrative centre in Vichy to the southeast of Paris. It was agreed under the Conditions of Armistice that while Germany controlled the northern and western French cities, the Vichy goverment would control the rest of France. While officially neutral in the war, Vichy actively collaborated with Germany. The Vichy Government was seen as a German puppet, and fought the USA during Operation Torch with the XIXth Vichy Army Corps, who were neutralised within 15 hours by a 400-strong French resistance force. The Vichy nation effectively ceased to exist in 1942 when Germany occupied the remainder of European France in retaliation for the Vichy Government making a deal with the Allies after Operation Torch.

TEXT.English: On September 1st 1939, infantry and tanks of Germany crossed the border of Poland to begin the conquest of the nation. Disappointed by the refusal of Poland to hand over the Danzig Corridor peacefully, they decided that military action was required to take the land forcefully. Two days later, the English-French alliance declared war on Germany to honour their Defense Treaty with Poland.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- Germany is at war with Poland.[NEWLINE]- England is at war with Germany.[NEWLINE]- France is at war with Germany.

TEXT.English: In autumn 1939, after Germany's attack on Poland, the Soviet Union demanded that Finland agree to move the border 25 kilometres back from Leningrad. It also demanded that Finland lease the Hanko Peninsula to the USSR for 30 years for the creation of a naval base. In exchange, the Soviet Union offered Finland a large part of Karelia ("two pounds of dirt for one pound of gold").[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Finnish government refused the Soviet demands. The Soviet General Staff were already drawing plans for an offensive. On November 26 the Soviets staged the Shelling of Mainila, an incident in which Soviet artillery shelled areas near the Russian village of Mainila, then announced that a Finnish artillery attack had killed Soviet troops. The Soviet Union demanded that Finland apologise for the incident and move their forces 25 kilometres from the border.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Finland denied any responsibility for the attack and refused to give in. The Soviet Union used it as the excuse to withdraw from the non-agression pact. On November 30 Soviet forces attacked with 23 divisions, totalling 450,000 men.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- USSR is at war with Finland.

TEXT.English: By the end of winter 1940 it became clear that the Russian forces were becoming exhausted, and German representatives suggested that Finland should negotiate with the Soviet Union. Russian casualties had been high and the situation was a source of political embarrassment for the Soviet regime. With the spring thaw approaching, the Russian forces risked becoming bogged down in the forests, and a draft of peace terms was presented to Finland on February 12 1940. Not only the Germans but also the Swedes were keen to see an end to the Winter War, as the latter feared the collapse of its neighbor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]By the end of February Finland had depleted their ammunition supplies. Also, the Soviet Union had finally succeeded in breaking through the Mannerheim Line. Finally on February 29 the Finnish government agreed to start negotiations. Finland proposed an armistice on March 5, but the Soviets declined the offer the next day. Fighting contined up to the day the peace treaty was signed on March 12.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- USSR and Finland make peace.

TEXT.English: Strategically, Denmark was relatively unimportant to Germany, except as a staging area for operations in Norway, and of course as a border nation to Germany which would have to be controlled in some way. The country is small and relatively flat, ideal territory for German army operations, and Denmark's small army had little hope of success in armed resistance. But in the early morning hours of April 9th 1940 a few Danish troops engaged the advancing German army.[NEWLINE]Norway was important to Germany for two primary reasons: as a base for naval units, including U-boats, to harass Allied shipping in the North Atlantic, and to secure shipments of iron-ore from Sweden through the port of Narvik. The long northern coastline was an excellent place to launch U-boat operations into the North Atlantic in order to attack British commerce. Germany was dependent on iron ore from Sweden and was worried, with justification, that the Allies would attempt to disrupt those shipments, 90 percent of which originated from Narvik.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- Germany is at war with Denmark and Norway.[NEWLINE]- Denmark and Norway join the Allies.

TEXT.English: Germany initiated Fall Gelb on the evening prior to and the night of 10th May 1940. During the late evening German forces occupied Luxemburg. In the night Army Group B launched its feint offensive into the Netherlands and Belgium. The French command reacted immediately, sending 1st Army Group north in accordance with Plan D. This move committed their best forces, diminished their fighting power through the loss of readiness and their mobility through the loss of fuel. That evening French and British forces crossed the Dutch border, finding the Dutch already in full retreat. The French and British air command was less effective than anticipated, and the German Luftwaffe qucikly obtained air superiority, depriving the Allies of key reconnaissance abilities and disrupting Allied communication and coordination. Unfortunately for the Allies, all of these decisions led to the fall of the Low Countries and France within a few months.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- Germany is at war with the Low Countries.[NEWLINE]- Low Countries join the Allies.

TEXT.English: The Pact of Steel, known formally as the Pact of Friendship and Alliance between Germany and Italy, was an agreement between Fascist Italy and Germany signed on May 22nd 1939, by the foreign ministers of each country, Count Galeazzo Ciano for Italy and Joachim von Ribbentrop for Germany. The Pact consisted of two parts: the first section was an open declaration of continuing trust and cooperation between Germany and Italy, whilst the second, a 'Secret Supplementary Protocol', encouraged a joint military and economic policy. This pact was enacted by Italy by declaring war on France and England on June 10th 1940.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- Italy and Germany form the Axis.[NEWLINE]- Italy is at war with the Allies.

TEXT.English: The Austro-Hungarian Empire had sided with Imperial Germany during World War I yet had collapsed following the defeat by the allies. Following the Treaty of Trianon the state of Hungary was cut in size and this caused much resentment. In order to satisfy such resentment, Germany and Italy implemented the Vienna Awards in 1938 and 1940 and this was subsequently followed by Hungary joining the Tripartite Pact in November 1940. Collusion was further heightened when the Arrow Cross Party later came to power. Romania had joined the Allied Powers in WWI and had received Transylvania from Hungary. After Germany and Italy had awarded Transylvania to Hungary, and the Soviet Union had taken Bessarabia, the fascist Iron Guard party came to power and Romania joined the Tripartite Pact on November 23, 1940. This was partly due to the Romanian desire for protection against the Soviet Union. Bulgaria had been on the losing side in WWI, losing territory to Serbia and Greece. During WWII, Germany needed military access through Bulgaria in order to attack Greece. Adolf Hitler promised the Bulgarian King Boris that Bulgaria would receive all the territory she had lost in return for Bulgaria joining the Axis. Boris agreed and signed the Pact on March 1, 1941.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- East Balkans joins the Axis.[NEWLINE]- East Balkans is at war with the Allies.

TEXT.English: On April 6th 1941, the German Army invaded northern Greece, while other elements launched an attack against Yugoslavia. The Metaxas Line was defended by the vastly underpowered Greek Eastern Macedonia Army Section. The line ran for 170 km along the River Nestos in the east, and then along the Bulgarian border as far as Mount Beles near the Yugoslav border. TEXT.English: At 3:15 am on June 22nd 1941, roughly three million Axis troops crossed the border into the Soviet Union. The contribution of the German allies would generally only begin to make itself felt somewhat further into the campaign. The surprise was complete: Stavka, alarmed by reports that German units approached the border in battle deployment, had at 00:30 am ordered to warn the border troops that war was imminent, but only a small number of units were alerted in time. The shock of impact stemmed less from the timing of the attack however than from the sheer number of Axis troops who struck into Soviet territory all at once. Aside from the roughtly 3.2 million German land forces engaged in or earmarked for the Eastern campaign, about five hundred thousand Romanian, Hungarian, Slovakian and Italian troops eventually accompanied the German forces, while Finland made a major contribution in the North.[NEWLINE]Finland only joined the battle against the Soviet Union after the USSR bombed Finnish military targets, accusing them of allowing the Germans to strike from their land. Both sides considered this the continuation of the Winter War of 1939-40.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- Axis is at war with USSR.[NEWLINE]- Finland is at war with USSR.

TEXT.English: After France had fallen in 1940, the United Kingdom was out of money. Franklin Roosevelt persuaded the US Congress to pass the Lend-Lease Act on March 11th 1941, which provided the United Kingdom and 37 other countries with US$50 billion dollars in military equipment and other supplies. After the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, the United States declared war on Japan on December 8th 1941. As Japan's ally Germany declared war on the United States on December 11th, even though it was not obliged to do so under the Tripartite Pact. Germany hoped that Japan would support them by attacking the Soviet Union. Japan did not oblige because it had signed a non-agression treaty with the Soviet Union. Instead, Germany's declaration largely removed any significant opposition to the United States joining the fight in the Europe theatre with full commitment.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- USA joins the Allies.[NEWLINE]- USA is at war with the Axis.

TEXT.English: Most historians place the beginning of the Second Sino-Japanese War at the Luo Kou Bridge incident on July 7th 1937. Some Chinese historians, however place the starting point at the Mukden Incident of September 18th 1931. Following the Mukden Incident, the Japanese Kwantung Army occupied Manchuria and established the puppet state of Manchukuo on February 18th 1932. Japan pressured China into recognising the independence of Manchukuo. Following the Luo Kou Bridge incident in 1937, the Japanese occupied Shanghai, Nanjing and Southern Shanxi in campaigns involving approximately 350,000 Japanese soldiers, and considerably more Chinese soldiers. The Luo Kou Bridge incident not only marked the beginning of an open, undeclared war between China and Japan, but also hastened the formation of the Kuomintang-Communist Party of China Second United Front. These pivotal events in the conflict between China and Japan are generally regarded as the beginning of World War II in the Pacific.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- Japan is at war with China.

TEXT.English: Japanese forces invaded parts of French Indo-China on September 22nd 1940. The move was not unexpected, and followed a demand for bases in the region made two months earlier. Japanese relations with the west had deteriorated steadily in recent years and the United States, having renounced the US-Japanese trade treaty of 1911, placed embargoes on exports to Japan of war and other materials. Siam taking advantage of the confusion in French Indo-China after the fall of France in Europe also declared war on France, and eventually succumbed to Japanese pressure to join in an alliance.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- Siam and Japan form Axis.[NEWLINE]- Axis is at war with France.

TEXT.English: At 04:30 Hawaiian Time, the minesweeper USS Condor spotted a midget submarine outside Pearl Harbor entrance and alerted the destroyer Ward. Ward carried out a fruitless search. The first shots fired and the first casualties in the attack occured when Ward attacked and sank a midget submarine at 06:37. On the morning of the attack, the Army's Opana Point station detected the Japanese planes, but the warning was interpreted by an untrained new officer at the new and only partially activated Intelligence Centre. Although the operators at Opana Point reported an aircraft sighting larger than anyhthing they had ever seen, the Intelligence Centre assumed the pending, scheduled arrival of six B-17 bombers was the cause because of the direction from which the aircraft were coming, and because the radar operators had only seen the first element of incoming attackers.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- USA joins the Allies.[NEWLINE]- China joins the Allies.[NEWLINE]- Philippines joins the Allies.[NEWLINE]- Dutch joins the Allies.[NEWLINE]- Axis is at war with the Allies.

TEXT.English: The Battle of Manchuria began on August 8th 1945, with the Soviet invasion of Manchukuo; the greater invasion would eventually include northern Korea, Sakhalin, and the Kuril Islands. It marked the initial and only military action of the Soviet Union against the Empire of Japan; at the Yalta Conference, it had agreed to Allied pleas to terminate the neutrality pact with Japan and enter the Pacific Theatre within three months after the end of war in Europe. The invasion began on August 8th, precisely three months after the German surrender. Japan's decision to surrender was made before the scale of the Soviet attack on Manchuria, Sakhalin and the Kuril Islands was known, but had the war continued, the Soviets had plans to invade Hokkaido well before the other Allied invasion of Kyushu.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]- USSR is at war with Axis.[NEWLINE]- USSR joins the Allies.
